I'm so glad! Thank you! I did it!
I've never had a chance to work together with a Japanese artist. Not yet. I was the first to say, "I'm so happy! I'm so happy! Thank you! I'm so happy!
I don't have much of a chance to say "I'm so happy! Not yet.
It's more than how it was.
Thank you!
Thank you very much.
I'm Cora.
Thank you very much.
Thank you very much. Thank you very much.
Yay! Thank you very much.
We were in the same place to begin with, weren't we?
That's right. That's why I wanted to talk to you.
We were both working as idols.We are both idols.
You don't talk much? We don't talk about the old days of Yuru Meibo.
We don't talk at all.
You don't talk because people don't ask you? Do you say when they ask?
Not at all.
I'm fine.
They don't ask.
I've got a lot on my mind.
I have a lot of things on my mind.
I'm more concerned about her now than in the past.
I'm worried about a lot of things.
I guess I can't mention them because I have so many questions I want to ask her.

I know a lot of people who knew her when she was an idol.

I wonder if they have it.
With Miss Kanna.
Have you met Miss Kanna?
I haven't seen her in person.
I'm looking forward to meeting her... and taking pictures of this, this, and this.
I'll definitely do it, and I'm sure it'll get a lot of attention.
I'm sure it's going to be a hit.
I'm sure it's going to be a buzz, but we've been working together since 2013, right?
You joined Yurumelma in 2013?
But I think it was 2013, like four years.
That's about the same time.
Seriously, it was like one year.
That's right. Momo hasn't changed since then, though.
Right.
I know I haven't changed either.
Neither of us have changed at all anymore. We're both still in variety and stuff.
You stayed the same.
Ten years at this rate.
You can talk like that now. That's amazing.
I couldn't speak at all.
I couldn't speak at all.
I'm on my own now.
I have to talk now.
Just a little bit.

Whoa, whoa, whoa.

Hello, hello, hello.
I like your teeth.
I like your teeth.
Like that.
Yeah, yeah, yeah.
Say you like my teeth.
I already freak myself out when I'm alone.
I know, I freak out when I'm all by myself.
All by yourself?
Yeah. I think it's a great thing.
It's difficult.
Do you ever think about what you should have said?
I mean, do you ever think to yourself, "I should have said it better that way"?
Do you worry about that?
No, I don't,
I just want to get better at speaking.
Even for you, are you a good speaker?
No, I'm not good. I'm good.
It's just the number of words, isn't it?
But on TV, it's not good to use too many words.
This one-line message was done so well by Chinatsu Wakatsuki that I steal it every time, but I learn from her technique.
I don't want to say powerful words in one line because the width of TV is limited.
Oh, I see.
It's like, so you're the type of person who talks wow like I do.

It's like the opening of Star Wars.
In that sense, Ana-chan is good at it.
Ana-chan is good with everyone at once in her direction. And Ana-chan is good at creating an aura that you can't hear unless everyone turns to Ana-chan at once.
No, no, it's unconscious, but....
That is sense, sense.

Oh, I see, that's true.
So, as someone who knows the old days, I think you're getting good enough.
That's right.
You're able to hold a conversation.
Yeah, I mean, it used to be impossible.

I thought, "Wow, I missed it.
I miss it so much.
And then there was a comment about how the way he talks is different.
I've heard comments about how the way you speak has changed.
I thought it was probably a newcomer.
That's right.
I didn't know how to vocalize. I was in a different dimension.
I couldn't talk to other people, not even the members, for years.
I couldn't even say good morning.
So you were afraid to say anything?
I couldn't speak.
During that period, I couldn't do interviews.
I didn't know how to speak.
Now it's like that.
I'm told by the MC that I need to be heard.
I'm told to be more vocal.
If it's a radio show, I'm just fine with my normal voice.
If I try harder, it changes the tone of my voice.
That's what I was thinking at that level.
But when I look at it from the perspective of someone who has done it recently
I think that's how they see it... they see how much they love it.
When I saw it, it was like when I really came in.
It was the first time I saw it, so it was like I was really in it, and it was like I was standing next to you.
I was like that too in the beginning. You know, the kind of thing mom calls shiolingo.

Like shiolingo, eitaso...
Oh, my God!

I'm in love with her.
I like her.
I'm in love with her.

As Ringo in love.

And when we went out together,
I was impressed by that, and when we went out together, he would say, "Sio is a hurricane! And I was like, "Oh, my God, he's a hurricane!
And he was just like that.
But you don't know if he was born that way.
But I know that behind the scenes and out in the open.
She's just the way she is.
Yes.
So, there was a lot of trial and error.
There are things that I admire.
You know, you try things out and evolve. Humans...
We grow.
That's right.
We evolve.
There are things that are different from before.
I'm easily told I'm acting, or making something, or doing something.
But I'm not! I didn't use to use the Kansai dialect at all.
But when I was on TV...
I thought I could use my Kansai accent more. I thought it would be better to use the Kansai accent on TV, so I did.
But now, if I speak in standard Japanese like I do now...
It's like when you stop using the Kansai dialect, you've sealed the deal.
It's like a character change.
Oh, people will say that?
Yes, they do.
A lot.
It's a pain in the ass, isn't it?
Yes, it is. No, but it's my native language, Kansai-ben.
But now that I'm here, when I talk to my family at home, I speak in standard Japanese.
Oh, really?
That's right. So it's just a quasi-Japanese language that you speak.
So you do it normally.
On the other hand, you might be doing it more if you speak in Kansai dialect.
It's about the same.
So it depends on the viewer's point of view
It depends on the point of view of the viewer.
It's totally different.
That's what I'm trying to say.
When I look at your work, it looks like you're doing your best, and I'm doing my best.
You were doing your best.
When I look at it now, I wonder what she's talking about,And now, when I look at it, I wonder what I'm talking about,
I think, "What am I talking about?
After I thought, "That's enough," I started putting things out as they were.
I thought that was the best way to express myself.
No, you're right. Yeah, yeah, yeah.

Yeah.

Yeah.

It started from moe,

Then, after that, it became more Yandere-esque,

Let's show it! It's like, "Let's bring out the negativity and the black side!
I think that was the beginning of the trend.
It was a good start.
Did it become easier? Yes, it did.

It was tough for a long time. To be honest.
It was tough,

I was not a new novice, not a fan or anything like that.
But,
